description: {"blocks":[{"key":"63lel","text":"This is a protocol to perform RNA fluorescent in situ hybridization (RNA-FISH) using hybridization chain reaction (HCR) on whole-mount samples of the brains of the fly Drosophila melanogaster and other insects, e.g. the jumping ant Harpegnathos saltator. Probes and HCR reagents are purchased from Molecular Instruments. This protocol is loosely based on the \"generic sample in solution\" protocol published by Molecular Instruments. Our modifications include the description of fixation conditions, counterstaining by Hoechst, and altered washes. Additionally, we use larger concentrations of probes and hairpins following the protocol described by Younger, Herre et al. 2020. We have successfully employed this protocol to stain insect brains with up to 4 different probe sets simultaneously (hairpins conjugated with Alexa Fluor 488, 546, 496, and 647).","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":168,"length":23},{"style":"italic","offset":232,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":298,"length":21},{"key":1,"offset":359,"length":72},{"key":2,"offset":795,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9rg11","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kevi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9i7h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"709B94A036A911ECBD30851F7CBC6798","url":"https://www.molecularinstruments.com/"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"07BE124036AA11ECBD30851F7CBC6798","url":"https://files.molecularinstruments.com/MI-Protocol-RNAFISH-GenericSolution-Rev7.pdf"}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Meg A. guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"8jdji","text":"WORKING PRACTICES:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6ba1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6s4bn","text":"Prepare all buffers using nuclease-free water. Use filter tips and nuclease-free tubes. If using spot plates, pre-clean them first with household bleach diluted 1:10 in water and then with 70% ethanol. Wear gloves and adhere to other practices aimed at minimizing RNA degradation in the sample. Working in a clean bench is not required if other RNAse-free practice are followed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fu1cl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"hjh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74r34","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dffht","text":"PROBE DESIGN:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f7j4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2d2nl","text":"We select the target sequence or isoform of the gene of interest and let Molecular Instruments design the probes. For genes with multiple isoforms, either target the isoform that includes as many as possible constitutive exons and as few as possible alternatively spliced exons, or the isoform that has the highest RNA-seq coverage (assessed visually in IGV) if RNA-seq data are available. Aim for the highest number of probes in a set, ideally 40, although we have successfully performed experiments with probe sets containing \u003c20 probes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69l1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"50m9f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e29nl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fn5om","text":"AMPLIFIER CHOICE:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5et1h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7v0dr","text":"We routinely perform multiplexed stainings with up to 4 different probe sets and a Hoechst counterstain. We use amplifiers conjugated with Alexa Fluor 488, 546, 594, and 647. We are able to detect clearly distinguishable signals with minimal bleed-through on our confocal microscope (Leica SP8). However, be aware that simultaneously using fluorophores with partially overlapping spectra (e.g. AF 546 and 594) requires setting narrower detection ranges, which reduces the amount of signal detected.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

28 and 29 add up to 3 h of incubation with Hoechst. In our experience, this is a minimum amount of time required for complete penetration of brains that are as large as the brain of an adult worker of Harpegnathos saltator. Still, the quality of Hoechst staining varies across experiments. In principle, incubation may be extended, but this may also increase the stringency of washes since Hoechst is diluted in 5X SSCT.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
